review.title: Assisted Energy Management in Smart Microgrids
review.abstract: Demand response provides utilities with a mechanism to share with end users the stochasticity resulting from the use of renewable sources. Pricing is accordingly used to reflect energy availability, to allocate such a limited resource to those loads that value it most. However, the strictly competitive mechanism can result in service interruption in presence of competing demand. To solve this issue we investigate on the use of forward contracts, i.e., service level agreements priced to reflect the expectation of future supply and demand curves. Given the limited resources of microgrids, service interruption is an opposite objective to the one of service availability. We firstly design policy-based brokers and identify then a learning broker based on artificial neural networks. We show the latter being progressively minimizing the reimbursement costs and maximizing the overall profit.

sections.heading: 4.2 Research questions
sections.text: As previously introduced, the broker seeks to maximize profit by correctly formulating the retail price of multiple deployment periods. As costs are determined by the get-and-fit plans, this leads to a correct reflection of future supply costs and expected demand in the retail price. This leads directly to the following distinction: i) a pessimistic broker who calculates SLAs proportionately to their duration (the longer the reserve, the higher the price), and ii) an optimistic broker who maintains the same price for all SLA terms. These strategies are useful as baseline reference. Accordingly, the pessimistic broker largely agrees with individual SLAs (i.e., the shortest price available), highlighting the problems of market competition and service disruption that motivate this study. On the other hand, the optimistic broker attributes the same uncertainty to all SLA terms (i.e., the shortest available price), which can lead to the most economically naive loss of such a number.
